questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician with his wife for evaluation of infertility. They have been unable to conceive for 2 years. The man reports normal libido and erectile function. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years. He does not take any medications. He has a history of right-sided cryptorchidism that was surgically corrected when he was 7 years of age. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Analysis of his semen shows a low sperm count. Laboratory studies are most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased placental ALP concentration can be seen in testicular cancers such as seminoma. Although this patient with cryptorchidism has an increased risk of developing testicular cancer, his normal physical examination (i.e., the absence of testicular enlargement) makes this diagnosis unlikely. Furthermore, testicular cancer does not typically cause infertility.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia (i.e., increased prolactin concentration) can cause infertility due to suppression of gonadotropin secretion. However, hyperprolactinemia typically presents with erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, and gynecomastia, all of which are absent in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Sertoli cells are essential for spermatogenesis, which is directly regulated by FSH and LH. FSH receptors are predominantly expressed in the Sertoli cells within the seminiferous tubules whereas LH receptors are predominantly expressed in the interstitial Leydig cells. As a feedback inhibition, Sertoli cells secrete inhibin B to suppress synthesis and secretion of FSH by the pituitary. In this patient with a history of cryptorchidism, Sertoli cell dysfunction would be expected due to temperature-induced damage to the seminiferous tubules, which can result in infertility. Therefore, inhibin B concentration would be decreased and FSH concentration would be increased (due to the loss of the feedback inhibition by inhibin B).

Orchidopexy is recommended in patients with cryptorchidism between 6â€“18 months of age to reduce the potential long-term complications of subfertility or infertility and the risk of testicular cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a history of cryptorchidism, dysfunction of the Sertoli cells (which are located in the walls of the seminiferous tubules) would be expected due to temperature-induced damage. Because Sertoli cells normally produce a substance that inhibits FSH secretion, FSH is increased (not decreased) in patients with Sertoli cell dysfunction

E) INCORRECT:

Androgen-binding proteins are produced by Sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubules of the testis and have a high affinity for androgens (e.g., 5 alpha-dihydrotestosterone (DHT) and testosterone). Because Sertoli cell dysfunction is common in patients with cryptorchidism, androgen-binding protein concentration would likely decrease, rather than increase.

F) INCORRECT:

Testosterone is secreted by Leydig cells under the stimulation of LH. Since Leydig cells are usually unaffected by temperature changes, decreased testosterone concentration is unlikely in this patient with a history of cryptorchidism. Moreover, the absence of findings of testosterone deficiency on physical examination (e.g., lack of secondary sexual characteristics) and normal libido make low testosterone concentration unlikely.
questions.hint: The location of the testes in the scrotum ordinarily allows them to be kept below body temperature. In patients with cryptorchidism, the undescended testis is exposed to comparatively higher temperatures. While testicular Sertoli cells are particularly sensitive to increased temperature, Leydig cells are not.

questions.text: Ten days after starting a new medication for major depressive disorder and insomnia, a 29-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 6-hour history of persistent, painful erection. Aspiration of fluid from which of the following is most likely to relieve this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The superficial dorsal vein drains the skin of the penis. It lies on the outside of the Buck fascia of the penis and drains into the external pudendal vein. Because it lies outside of erectile tissue, it is protected from the high pressures that prevent venous outflow during priapism. Aspiration of the superficial dorsal vein would not relieve the symptoms of priapism.

B) INCORRECT:

The deep dorsal vein drains blood from the glans penis, corpus spongiosum, and the distal parts of the corpus cavernosum. While it lies deep to the Buck fascia, it is superficial to the tunica albuginea and is therefore protected from the high pressures that prevent venous outflow during priapism. Aspiration of the deep dorsal vein would not relieve the symptoms of priapism.

C) INCORRECT:

The dorsal artery of the penis supplies blood to the tunica albuginea, glans, and prepuce, and is located deep to the Buck fascia but superficial to the tunica albuginea. It is not responsible for blood supply to the erectile tissues. Aspiration of the dorsal artery would neither reduce blood flow into erectile bodies nor improve venous outflow during priapism.

D) CORRECT:

Vasodilation of the small vessels in the corpus cavernosum is part of the physiologic mechanism of a penile erection. Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant with alpha-1 receptor antagonistic effects that can lead to increased blood flow to the corpus cavernosum and priapism. When an erection is sustained for prolonged periods, as in low-flow priapism, high pressures within the corpus cavernosum prevent venous outflow. First-line treatment includes aspiration of blood from the corpus cavernosum and injection of phenylephrine to reduce blood flow to this compartment. Without treatment, this patient is at risk of irreversible ischemia and chronic erectile dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

The corpus spongiosum surrounds the penile urethra. In order to protect the penile urethra and maintain its patency for ejaculation, the corpus spongiosum does not become engorged with blood during an erection. Therefore, aspiration of fluid from the corpus spongiosum would not be an appropriate treatment for priapism. Furthermore, aspiration of this compartment would also place the penile urethra at risk of injury.
questions.hint: The history of major depressive disorder with insomnia indicates that this patient was likely started on trazodone, which is known to cause priapism. Immediate drainage of the corpus cavernosum is indicated to prevent ischemia.

questions.text:
An investigator studying testicular cells introduces a mutation that selectively impairs Leydig cell function. This mutation results in hypoplasia of Leydig cells and prevents hormone production within them, without affecting the remaining testicular cells. A patient with this mutation is most likely to have which of the following sets of laboratory changes?



Luteinizing hormone
Follicle-stimulating hormone
Testosterone
Inhibin B



A
Decreased
normal
increased
normal


B
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased


C
Normal
increased
normal
decreased


D
Increased
increased
decreased
decreased


E
Increased
normal
decreased
normal
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hormone-secreting Leydig cell tumor would increase testosterone levels, which would provide negative feedback to the pituitary gland and therefore decrease LH release. FSH and inhibin B would not be affected, as they are involved in the endocrine regulation of Sertoli cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased gonadotropin (FSH and LH) levels could indicate dysfunction of the hypothalamus (e.g., in Kallmann syndrome) and/or the pituitary gland. Low gonadotropin levels would cause decreased stimulation of both Sertoli cells and Leydig cells, which would result in decreased testosterone and inhibin B levels (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism).

C) INCORRECT:

A genetic mutation inhibiting the function of Sertoli cells would decrease secretion of inhibin B, a hormone that inhibits FSH release from the pituitary gland. Decreased inhibin B secretion would decrease the negative feedback on FSH release in the pituitary gland, resulting in increased pituitary secretion of FSH. LH and testosterone levels would not be affected, as they are involved in the endocrine regulation of Leydig cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of both Leydig cells and Sertoli cells or absence of testis (e.g., after surgical removal) would lead to decreased testosterone and inhibin B levels. This, in turn, would decrease negative feedback to the pituitary gland, which would lead to increased secretion of LH and FSH (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism).

E) CORRECT:

Leydig cells in the testicular interstitium are responsible for the secretion of testosterone, which is converted into dihydrotestosterone by 5Î±-reductase. Luteinizing hormone (LH) is secreted by the pituitary gland and stimulates testicular Leydig cells to synthesize testosterone. A genetic mutation selectively inhibiting the function of Leydig cells would decrease testosterone production, which would stimulate LH release in the pituitary gland through decreased negative feedback. The mutation would not affect FSH or inhibin B, as these hormones are involved in the endocrine regulation of Sertoli cells.
questions.hint: Leydig cells are responsible for the production of a hormone that is converted into the more potent form by the enzyme 5Î±-reductase.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for a wellness visit. Physical examination shows an enlarged and nodular prostate. Laboratory studies show elevated levels of prostate-specific antigen. A prostate biopsy confirms the diagnosis of prostate cancer and a radical prostatectomy is planned. This patient should be counseled on the increased risk of injury to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The cavernous nerve can be injured during radical prostatectomy. The resulting erectile dysfunction is one of the most feared complications of radical prostatectomy, but advances in urological surgery have enabled safer approaches that have significantly reduced the risk of permanent impotence.

B) INCORRECT:

The superior vesical artery courses along the upper part of the bladder. This course keeps it safely away from the surgical field typically involved in radical prostatectomy. In modern prostate surgery, the risk of vascular injury is roughly 0.2%, making this a rare complication.

C) INCORRECT:

The external anal sphincter is not at risk during radical prostatectomy. This structure can be compromised during traumatic vaginal births that lead to perineal lacerations. Radical prostatectomy can, however, pose a risk to the external urinary sphincter.

D) INCORRECT:

Injuries to the hypogastric nerve are very uncommon in radical prostatectomy. The course of this nerve is much too proximal to be compromised in the typical surgical approach to the prostate.

E) INCORRECT:

Injury to the ureter is very rare during radical prostatectomy. Published rates of ureter injury are about 0.1% in large studies. Rather, urethral strictures are more likely, resulting from scarring that can occur near the bladder trigone following radical prostatectomy.
questions.hint: Radical prostatectomy involves complete removal of the prostate, including the prostatic capsule, the seminal vesicles, and the vas deferens.

questions.text: An investigator is conducting an experiment to study different pathways of glucose metabolism. He obtains cells cultured from various tissues to study the effect of increased extracellular glucose concentration. Following the incubation of these cells in 5% dextrose, he measures the intracellular fructose concentration. The concentration of fructose is expected to be highest in cells obtained from which of the following tissues?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ovarian, seminal vesicle, and liver cells express both aldose reductase, which reduces glucose to sorbitol, and sorbitol dehydrogenase, which converts sorbitol to fructose. Therefore, glucose can be converted into fructose in these tissues, and intracellular fructose concentrations are expected to be high in this experiment.

In this experiment, fructose concentrations would be expected to be highest in liver cells, since they do not express hexokinase, which converts fructose into fructose-6-phosphate.
Image Description:

During hyperglycemic states, excess glucose is shunted from the hexokinase/glycolysis pathway into various other metabolic pathways. Cells containing aldose reductase convert glucose to sorbitol, which is then converted into fructose. Organs lacking sorbitol dehydrogenase (red) accumulate sorbitol, resulting in osmotic damage.

B) INCORRECT:

Kidney cells express aldose reductase, which reduces glucose to sorbitol, but they lack sorbitol dehydrogenase and cannot convert sorbitol to fructose. Therefore, intracellular fructose concentrations are not expected to be high in this experiment. Accumulation of sorbitol due to chronic hyperglycemia in uncontrolled diabetes mellitus can cause osmotic damage in kidney cells (i.e., diabetic nephropathy).

C) INCORRECT:

Schwann cells, which form the myelin sheaths of peripheral nerves, express aldose reductase, which reduces glucose to sorbitol. However, they lack sorbitol dehydrogenase and cannot convert sorbitol to fructose. Therefore, intracellular fructose concentrations are not expected to be high in this experiment. Accumulation of sorbitol due to chronic hyperglycemia in uncontrolled diabetes mellitus can cause osmotic damage in Schwann cells (i.e., diabetic neuropathy).

D) INCORRECT:

Lens cells primarily express aldose reductase, which converts glucose into sorbitol. Sorbitol dehydrogenase, which converts sorbitol into fructose, is only expressed at low levels, which are not sufficient to metabolize high concentrations of sorbitol. Therefore, intracellular fructose concentrations are not expected to be high in this experiment. Accumulation of sorbitol due to chronic hyperglycemia in uncontrolled diabetes mellitus can cause osmotic damage in lens cells (i.e., diabetic cataract).

E) INCORRECT:

Retinal cells express aldose reductase, which reduces glucose to sorbitol, but they lack sorbitol dehydrogenase and cannot convert sorbitol to fructose. Therefore, intracellular fructose concentrations are not expected to be high in this experiment. Accumulation of sorbitol due to chronic hyperglycemia in uncontrolled diabetes mellitus can cause osmotic damage in retinal cells (i.e., diabetic retinopathy).
questions.hint: Glucose is converted into fructose in two steps: glucose is first reduced into sorbitol, which can then be converted into fructose. Consequently, fructose concentration is expected to be highest in cells that express both enzymes needed for these reactions.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man undergoes surgical repair of a left-sided inguinal hernia. During the preparation of the left superficial inguinal ring, the spermatic cord is injured and one of the arteries passing through the cord is cut. The surgeon finds that both the artery of the ductus deferens and the cremasteric artery are still intact. The third, damaged artery is most likely a branch of which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The artery of the ductus deferens branches from the anterior division of the internal iliac artery and travels within the spermatic cord before terminating (anastomosis with the testicular artery). Damage to the artery of the ductus deferens, which supplies the ductus deferens and seminal vesicles, can occur during inguinal hernia repair. However, the surgeon found the artery of the ductus deferens to be intact, suggesting that another vessel was damaged.
Image Description:

Longitudinal section of the pelvis

B) INCORRECT:

Branches of the renal artery primarily provide blood to the kidney, adrenal gland, and ureter, rather than the testis. The left testicular vein, which drains the pampiniform plexus, empties into the left renal vein. While the pampiniform plexus does encapsulate the spermatic cord, the surgeon damaged an artery, not a vein.
Image Description:

Branches of the abdominal aorta:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)

Tributaries of the inferior vena cava:
- Main confluencing tributaries: right and left common iliac veins and the median sacral vein
- Lateral tributaries: bilateral renal veins, right gonadal vein (the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein), right suprarenal vein (the left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein), lumbar veins, and inferior phrenic veins
- Anterior tributaries: hepatic veins

Note: As the left renal vein passes in front of the aorta, underneath the superior mesenteric artery, it is susceptible to compression between these structures, known as nutcracker phenomenon.

C) INCORRECT:

The femoral artery originates from the external iliac artery at the base of the femoral triangle. Although rare during an inguinal hernia repair, damage to the femoral artery can occur following fixation of the mesh to the inguinal ligament. However, the surgeon damaged the spermatic cord, which neither the femoral artery nor one of its branches runs through.
Image Description:

Longitudinal section of the pelvis

D) INCORRECT:

The cremasteric artery branches from the inferior epigastric artery and travels within the spermatic cord before terminating (anastomosis with the testicular artery). Damage to the cremasteric artery, which supplies layers of the spermatic cord and scrotal skin, can also occur during an inguinal hernia repair. However, the surgeon found the cremasteric artery to be intact, suggesting that another vessel was damaged.

E) CORRECT:

The abdominal aorta branches around L2 into the paired testicular arteries, which serve as the primary blood supply to the testes. The testicular artery's course within the spermatic cord makes it susceptible to injury during inguinal hernia repair. Collateral blood supply is provided by branches of the cremasteric artery and artery of the ductus deferens, which anastomose with the main testicular artery distally.

The female anatomical equivalent of the gonadal artery is the ovarian artery, which also branches from the abdominal aorta to supply the ovaries. If injured, the uterine artery, which anastomoses with the ovarian artery distally, provides collateral blood supply to the ovaries.
Image Description:

There are:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)

Note that the superior suprarenal artery originates from the inferior phrenic artery, while the inferior suprarenal artery originates from the renal artery.

F) INCORRECT:

The umbilical artery is a remnant of fetal circulation. In adults, an obliterated portion becomes the medial umbilical ligament, while a patent segment becomes the superior vesical artery. The superior vesical artery does not run through the spermatic cord, which the surgeon damaged.

G) INCORRECT:

The internal pudendal artery branches off the internal iliac artery to supply the external genitalia. However, the surgeon damaged the spermatic cord, which the internal pudendal artery and its branches do not run through.
Image Description:

Longitudinal section of the pelvis
questions.hint: The spermatic cord contains three arteries: testicular artery, artery of the ductus deferens, and cremasteric artery.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of swelling and unusual heaviness of his scrotum that he first noticed a few weeks ago. The symptoms improve when he is lying in bed. He also reports a 5-kg (11-lbs) weight loss and increasing fatigue over the past 6 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of his right flank. There are soft strands palpable in the right hemiscrotum superior of the right testis. The strands increase with Valsalva maneuver. Applying a bright light to the right hemiscrotum shows no transillumination. Obstruction of venous drainage into which of the following vessels is most likely responsible for this patient's scrotal enlargement?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Venous blood drainage from the anterior scrotum occurs via the external pudendal veins into the great saphenous vein. However, the palpable strands (i.e., â€œbag of wormsâ€) in the right hemiscrotum developed due to dilatation of the pampiniform plexus, which receives blood from the testes rather than the scrotum. Obstruction of the right external pudendal vein would not cause a right-sided varicocele.

B) INCORRECT:

Venous blood return from the prostate travels via the prostatic venous plexus to the internal iliac veins and can provide a route for the hematogenous spread of prostate cancer metastases or infections to the spine. The right testicular vein, however, does not drain into the right internal iliac vein, so obstruction would not cause a right-sided varicocele.

C) INCORRECT:

The inferior rectal veins, part of the systemic circulation, drain the rectum below the dentate line and connect with the portal system via anastomosis with the superior rectal veins. Due to this anastomosis, portal hypertension can lead to anorectal varices. Obstruction of the right inferior rectal vein would not cause a right-sided varicocele because the right testicular vein does not drain into the right inferior rectal vein.

D) INCORRECT:

While the left testicular vein empties into the left renal vein, the right testicular vein does not empty into the right renal vein. Obstruction of the left renal vein (e.g., nutcracker syndrome, thrombosis) can result in a left-sided varicocele, but this patient's right-sided scrotal enlargement cannot be explained by right renal vein obstruction.

E) CORRECT:

Unilateral right-sided varicoceles arise due to obstruction of right pampiniform venous plexus drainage via the testicular vein into the inferior vena cava (IVC). Varicoceles are more commonly left-sided, because the left testicular vein drains into the relatively high-pressure left renal vein at a 90-degree angle, while the right testicular vein drains into the low-pressure IVC. Unilateral right-sided varicoceles should raise suspicion for a mass in the retroperitoneal space (e.g., renal cell carcinoma, lymphoma, Ormond disease) blocking the venous blood return. This patient's history of weight loss, fatigue, smoking history, and right flank tenderness is concerning for an underlying right-sided renal cell carcinoma obstructing the right testicular vein and causing the varicocele.
Image Description:

Branches of the abdominal aorta:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)

Tributaries of the inferior vena cava:
- Main confluencing tributaries: right and left common iliac veins and the median sacral vein
- Lateral tributaries: bilateral renal veins, right gonadal vein (the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein), right suprarenal vein (the left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein), lumbar veins, and inferior phrenic veins
- Anterior tributaries: hepatic veins

Note: As the left renal vein passes in front of the aorta, underneath the superior mesenteric artery, it is susceptible to compression between these structures, known as nutcracker phenomenon.
questions.hint: Presentation with right scrotal swelling and heaviness, exacerbated by Valsalva maneuver and alleviated by recumbency, in combination with palpable strands (i.e., â€œbag of wormsâ€) and a negative transillumination test on examination suggests a right-sided varicocele.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of swelling and unusual heaviness of his scrotum that he first noticed a few weeks ago. The symptoms improve when he is lying in bed. He also reports a 5-kg (11-lbs) weight loss and increasing fatigue over the past 6 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of his right flank. There are soft strands palpable in the right hemiscrotum superior of the right testis. The strands increase with Valsalva maneuver. Applying a bright light to the right hemiscrotum shows no transillumination. Venous blood drainage from the anterior scrotum occurs via the external pudendal veins into the great saphenous vein. However, the palpable strands (i.e., â€œbag of wormsâ€) in the right hemiscrotum developed due to dilatation of the pampiniform plexus, which receives blood from the testes rather than the scrotum. Obstruction of the right external pudendal vein would not cause a right-sided varicocele.

B) INCORRECT:

The right testicular vein, however, does not drain into the right internal iliac vein, so obstruction would not cause a right-sided varicocele.

The inferior rectal veins, part of the systemic circulation, drain the rectum below the dentate line and connect with the portal system via anastomosis with the superior rectal veins. Due to this anastomosis, portal hypertension can lead to anorectal varices. Obstruction of the right inferior rectal vein would not cause a right-sided varicocele because the right testicular vein does not drain into the right inferior rectal vein.

While the left testicular vein empties into the left renal vein, the right testicular vein does not empty into the right renal vein. Unilateral right-sided varicoceles arise due to obstruction of right pampiniform venous plexus drainage via the testicular vein into the inferior vena cava (IVC). Branches of the abdominal aorta:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)

Tributaries of the inferior vena cava:
- Main confluencing tributaries: right and left common iliac veins and the median sacral vein
- Lateral tributaries: bilateral renal veins, right gonadal vein (the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein), right suprarenal vein (the left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein), lumbar veins, and inferior phrenic veins
- Anterior tributaries: hepatic veins

Note: As the left renal vein passes in front of the aorta, underneath the superior mesenteric artery, it is susceptible to compression between these structures, known as nutcracker phenomenon.
questions.hint: Presentation with right scrotal swelling and heaviness, exacerbated by Valsalva maneuver and alleviated by recumbency, in combination with palpable strands (i.e., â€œbag of wormsâ€) and a negative transillumination test on examination suggests a right-sided varicocele.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of testicular swelling and dull lower abdominal discomfort. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender left testicular nodule. Ultrasonography of the scrotum shows a well-defined hypoechoic lesion of the left testicle. Serum studies show an elevated Î²-hCG concentration and a normal Î±-fetoprotein concentration. The patient undergoes a radical inguinal orchiectomy. Histopathologic examination of the surgical specimen shows a mixed germ cell tumor with invasion of adjacent lymphatic vessels. Further evaluation is most likely to show malignant cells in which of the following lymph node regions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The external iliac lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage for the superior part of the bladder. They are not common sites of metastasis for testicular cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

The inferior mesenteric lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage for most of the large intestine (from the splenic flexure through the upper rectum, including the superior and sigmoid rectum). They are not common sites of metastasis for testicular cancer.
Image Description:

Lymph is ultimately drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct only drains roughly the upper right area of the body (green), whereas the thoracic duct is responsible for the rest of the body. The deep lymph nodes are not palpable.

C) INCORRECT:

The internal iliac lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage for the prostate, corpus cavernosum, bladder, and the lower rectum (to the anal canal above the dentate line). They are not common sites of metastasis for testicular cancer.
Image Description:

Lymph is ultimately drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct only drains roughly the upper right area of the body (green), whereas the thoracic duct is responsible for the rest of the body. The deep lymph nodes are not palpable.

D) INCORRECT:

The mediastinal lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage for the trachea and esophagus. Although malignant cells can appear in these nodes (as well as the hilar lymph nodes, which drain the lungs) if testicular cancers metastasize to the pulmonary system, this is not the primary region of lymphatic drainage for the testes. It is therefore less likely to have malignant cells than other lymph node clusters.
Image Description:

Lymph is ultimately drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct only drains roughly the upper right area of the body (green), whereas the thoracic duct is responsible for the rest of the body. The deep lymph nodes are not palpable.

E) CORRECT:

The para-aortic lymph nodes are the most common site of metastasis for testicular cancer. Lymphatic fluid travels up the path of testicular descent through the inguinal canal, following the testicular arteries back to the abdominal aorta, where they originate, near the site of early gonadal development and differentiation of the mesonephros. The kidneys also drain to these lymph nodes.

Until proven otherwise, a firm nodule on the testis should be considered cancer.
Image Description:

Lymph is ultimately drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct only drains roughly the upper right area of the body (green), whereas the thoracic duct is responsible for the rest of the body. The deep lymph nodes are not palpable.

F) INCORRECT:

The superficial inguinal lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage from the scrotum and distal anus up to the dentate line. They are not common sites of metastasis for testicular cancer.

G) INCORRECT:

The deep inguinal lymph nodes are the primary sites of lymphatic drainage for the glans penis and anterior urethra. They are not common sites of metastasis for testicular cancer.
questions.hint: This patient has a primary testicular cancer, which typically spreads through the lymphatic system. To remember which lymph nodes drain the testes, it is helpful to recall their location in early embryological development.
